title: scottish-parliament-recess-happens-mean-scotland
story: The Scottish Parliament is on recess from October  - , meaning chamber meetings and ministerial statments will not take place this week.Parliament recesses are breaks from normal order and usually take place several times a year in line with school and bank holidays.What do these recesses mean for politicsin Scotland  Heres everything you need to know...What areParliament recesses Parliament recesses arebreaks in the normal schedule when there are no meetings in the Chamber and no committee meetings.The Ocotberrecess is often seen as an "October holiday" for MSPs, althoughit is unlikely they will take the whole recess to recuperate.Do MSPs continue working during Parliament recess The recess allows MSPs to spend an extended period of time in their own constituencyand therefore with their constituents.MSPs are likely to take advantage of this time to maintain or increase rapport with their constituents by attending local events and generally keeping a fairly high profile.Recesses give MSPs time to make the visits that they might in normal times be too busy to carry out.Do First Ministers Questions continue during recess No, First Ministers Questions will not continue during recess.However, Parliament can be recalled over the course ofrecessrequired.Can Parliament berecalled at any time Parliament can be recalled from recess on request of the Government.For example, Parliament was recalled during recess in April following the death of Prince Philipto allow politicians in Scotlandto pay tribute to the Duke of Edinburgh.Can I still contact my MSP during Parliamentary recess Yes, you can still get in contact with your MSP during recesses and they may table questions to ask when Parliament s.When does the UK Parliament take nextrecess The UK Parliament will takerecess from November -.

title: christmas-shortages-2021-homemade-christmas-gift-ideas
story: With warnings of Christmas shortages due to supply chain issues and delivery delays, you might be thinking about giving homemade gts this year.Covid- and Brexitare among contributing factors, while an escalating dispute over fishing rights has led French fishing representatives to threaten a blockade at Calais to stop exports to the UK.Current issues have been put down to a "transition period" by Boris Johnsons administration, which they say will not cause "much risk" at Christmas.However, asindustry experts deemChristmas shortages "a certainty", making your own presents could help you to avoid potential delays or disappointment.Not only that, but family and friends are sure to appreciate the time andeffort that goes into creating ahand crafted gt.Here are some ideas for homemade presents this Christmas.... Homemade jam and chutneyThe festive period is a time for eating, so what better than cooking up a big batch of homemade jam or chutney for your loved ones.Start saving your jars now and by Christmas you will have plenty to fill.Hundreds of recipescan be found online andyou are cooking in large quantities, it wont necessarily be that expensive!Another positive is the long shelf le of such products, meaning people can enjoy them well into .. Christmas decorationsChristmas tree decorationsare an underrated gt - with people using the same items year after year, and even generation after generation, this could be your opportunity to leave your stamp on celebrations for decades to come.There are plenty of ideas online, but why not buy some cheap, clear plastic or glass bobbles which you can decorate with permanent markers, tippex pens or paint, before tying with ribbon.Baked salt dough can work just as well, while simple origami folding techniques can be used to transform a piece of paper into something special.. Photo albumsA photo album filled with memories could be the best present someone ever receives.It may be slightly time consuming, but a collection of photos reminding your loved ones of a special time in their le is a timeless classic which will never get old.Photo albums can be cheaply purchasedonline or in store - charity shops are a good place to start - and companieslike Free Printsmean you can order photographs for free from your phone.. Knitted socksIf you are a keen knitter, homemade socks are guaranteed to please as well as keep people warm through the cold winter months.. Sloe ginSloe gin is synonymous with aChristmas tipple, and as it turns out its pretty easy to make yourself, with some recipes only requiring three ingredients.Again, start saving bottles and by December you will be ready to decant.. Christmas bakingYou cant go wrong with some Christmas baking, whether it be mince pies, yule logs or mini Christmas puddings.Pop it in a box and tie with ribbon and you have yourself the perfect gt which will go down a treat while people wait for Christmas dinner.. VouchersIf you dont want to give physical gts, you could make a voucher for an experience to take your loved one out for coffee or dinner once the festive season is over.Its something to look forward to once Christmas is over, and gives you a chance to catch up on each others lives after the busy end-of-year period.

title: stirling-city-culture-scottish-city-makes-longlist---means
story: Stirling has been longlisted for the City of Culture , along with sevenother cities around the UK.It was one of three Scottish areas to apply, but the only one to make this years longlist in title: minato-sushi-cheese-lady-boost-haddington-town-centre
story: The Cheese Lady on Haddington High Street is moving into the former butcher premises of Colin D Peat on neighbouring Court Street.The move from High Street has opened the door for Minato Sushi to bring the Japanese delicacy to the town centre.The changing face of the town centre was welcomed by councillors Tom Trotter and John McMillan, with the new businesses set to open this summer.Jen Kerr, of Minato Sushi, stressed there was still plenty of work ahead at the business before the doors opened.The -year-old, of Port Seton, who will run the business with her boyfriend Tom Cuddy, described it as ldquoa real dream come true.She said: ldquoWe are really excited. It is quite a big town centre in East Lothian and has quite a erse mix of businesses there already. It seems nice and some people have been coming up and chatting to me and other shop owners have been quite friendly.Meanwhile, Svetlana Kukharchuk ndash The Cheese Lady ndash has ambitious plans for the former butchers having found a home for her business in the town nearly four years ago.She said: ldquoWe needed more space and wanted to expand so we can offer more space to our customers to shop more conveniently.ldquoWe want to mature our own cheeses and we are going to have a maturation room.ldquoAlso, Irsquom hoping to offer a few tables, which still needs to be confirmed with the council, where people can sit down and order a flight of cheese and a glass of wine.Svetlana, who previously had a business in St Andrews, moved to East Lothian in November  and opened her High Street shop.The business has proven a popular addition to the town centre, offering cheeses from throughout Europe, including Italy, France, Spain, Switzerland and Norway.Mr Trotter was pleased with the announcement regarding the two businesses.He said: ldquoWhoever thought a cheese shop in Haddington that, after this time, needed bigger premises  Thatrsquos fantastic.ldquoAnd it is incredible we are getting a sushi shop.Fellow ward member Mr McMillan was pleased with the level of interest from people looking to open up businesses in the town.He said: ldquoI think we are in a good place.ldquoWhen we were growing up, we did not know what sushi was!

title: youngsters-12-hour-non-stop-relay-boosts-walk-scott-foundation
story: Mary Kidd spent a day running, cycling, skipping and more in aid of the Walk With Scott Foundation.The -hour non-stop relay on May  has collected more than pound,, which will go to the Tranent-based charity.Proud mum Karen is secretary of the Walk With Scott Foundation, which was set up by after-dinner speaker Scott Glynn to mark his th birthday.Karen thanked everyone who sponsored her -year-old daughter, who also undertook a fundraiser for the charity last year during lockdown.Karen said: ldquoWe are all so very proud of Mary once again, with her amazingly crazy two fundraising events.ldquoMary has raised a fantastic pound, for the Walk with Scott Foundation and I know first-hand how much these funds are going to help others across our communities.Last year, the primary six pupil at Cockenzie Primary School completed a six-hour TikTok marathon, which raised pound, for the Walk With Scott Foundation.: Familys television appearanceThe success of the fundraiser even caught the attention of former Spandau Ballet and EastEnders star Martin Kemp and his son Roman. Mary and Karen were joined by dad Gordon and older sister Abbie on Martin and Romanrsquos Sunday Best TV show to discuss the success of the event.However, Mary was not content to put her feet up and was once again doing her bit for the good cause.Speaking ahead of the latest fundraiser, Mary said: ldquoThis year I want to double the time, and plan to do a -hour non-stop fun relay up and down our Lorimer Lane at the back of my house.ldquoIrsquom walking, running, skipping, hopping, jumping, scootering, cycling, skating, football dribbling, swing ball, space hopping and, of course, TikTok-ing!People can still sponsor Mary by going to uk.virginmoneygiving marysfunrelay

title: musician-brings-back-fond-memories-musselburgh-nursing-home
story: Dr Claire Garabedian and her nine-year-old terrier Rusty visited Harbour House, near Fisherrow Harbour, where she met residents, relatives and staff.She played well-known songs such as My Bonnie, You Are My Sunshine and Over The Rainbow, free improvisations and classical music.She said: ldquoBetween tunes, I asked and welcomed questions, and I explained a bit about what music can do towards encouraging connection and engagement ndash a sonic haven ndash and what I do as a therapeutic musician.Rusty, who Claire rehomed last November, was also a big hit with the audience. She said: ldquoHe is partially blind with cataracts and a social opportunist. He simply loves being around people and is very gentle and intuitive.Claire, who lives near Harbour House, would like to extend her performances in nursing and care homes to people living in their own homes.She said: ldquoWhile playing for a small group is fun and effective, the smaller the group, all the way down to one-to-one, the more effectively the music can be towards facilitating connection.Claire is a professional cellist, baroque cellist and therapeutic musician whose doctoral and post-doctoral research focuses on effectively using the arts, especially music, as a means of engagement and a connection with people who are living with dementia, including family and friends.She said: ldquoIrsquove found that music can generate connections and equality among all who are present ndash listening or playing music together regardless of any physical cognitive conditions.Claire has enjoyed sharing her knowledge and experiences on some big stages, such as the Hay Festival and BBC Radio  .A Harbour House spokesperson said: ldquoThe residents said they found Clairersquos performance both calming and relaxing. Some commented on how the songs played brought back some fond memories. There was lots of reminiscing following Clairersquos visit.More information about Claire and her work can be found at drclairegarabedian

title: call-green-fingered-volunteers-wallyford
story: The community initiative lsquoWallyford in Bloomrsquo has been launched by The Destiny Project SCIO, a mental health charity.Andrew Stevenson, the charityrsquos project manager, said: ldquoThe main aim of the initiative is to bring people together that live and work in Wallyford.ldquoWe want to create a bloom of colour within the village.He explained that Wallyford in Bloom was linked with the projectrsquos adoption of Wallyford Railway Station as part of ScotRailrsquos lsquoAdopt a Stationrsquo scheme.He said: ldquoWe are appealing to the people of Wallyford of all ages to come join us to contribute in the delivery of Wallyford in Bloom.Enthusiastic fundraisers were also welcome to support the charity and lsquoIn Bloomrsquo initiative.Mr Stevenson said: ldquoWallyford is a place I spent a brief part of my childhood and is a special place to me.He added: ldquoWe aim to create a little colour with planters throughout the village and would also like to create an lsquoAdopt Your Streetrsquo project to promote litter picking.ldquoThe main aim is to bring people together from all walks of le and to promote the importance of the environment. We currently have a handful of volunteers, with many more interested, but there is always room for more.It is hoped to involve local children in the railway station project by asking them to create their own rock drawings of their favourite things about where they live.ldquoThis will surround a large lsquoWALLYFORDrsquo on the mound at the  in the shape of a carriage. There will also be the shape of a train with flowers within it, with the objective to promote the STEAM fields of science, technology, engineering, art and maths, Mr Stevenson added.Anyone interested in getting involved with Wallyford in Bloom can email Mr Stevenson at andrewthedestinyproject@gmail or check out the Wallyford in Bloom and Destiny Project Facebook pages.The Destiny Project provides support and advocacy to communities.It works with other agencies to provide a wide range of services, particularly for the most vulnerable in the community.The charity promotes the health and wellbeing of children and young people, building skills that will create a positive impact on their lives by working on matters such as education and training, and the environment.The project recognises the ldquoimportant role that volunteers play in communities and aims to actively encourage and support its volunteers.

title: dunbar-community-woodland-group-boosted-viridor
story: Dunbar Community Woodland Groupwas given pound, by Viridor, as it toasted the safety record at its nearby Energy Recovery Facilityndash the site recording zero lost time injuriessince it became operational in January .Dunbar Community Woodland Group was nominated for the donation by Sue Anderson, visitor centre officer at the ERF, which is based at Oxwellmains, east of the town.She said: ldquoDunbar is so lucky to have Lochend Woods and, although itrsquos up to all of us to look after them, the work of the DCWG volunteers in planting trees, maintaining the paths and managing the woodland for the benefit of wildle and the community is to be applauded and Irsquom delighted Viridor is supporting them.

title: preston-lodge-high-school-supporting-aidan-hogg-dress-day
story: Aidan Hogg, an S student, has been receiving treatment at Edinburghrsquos Royal Hospital for Children and Young People after his leukaemia diagnosis in March.He recently completed his final round of chemotherapy.Now, students at his school are supporting his Christmas bag appeal ndash named Aidanrsquos Magical Gts.Staff and students are being asking to wear something in their house colours ndash red, blue and yellow ndash on Fridayand donate pound during registration.House points will be awarded for those taking part.

title: honorary-consulate-czech-republic-officially-opens-musselburgh
story: The Czech Republicrsquos last Honorary Consul, Dr Paul Millar, retired recently after -plus years of service to the Czech community in Scotland, and his honorary consulate in Edinburgh closed its doors. A new Honorary Consul, Veronika MacLeod, has been appointed and she will be based on Eskside West.The tape was cut yesterdayby Czech deputy foreign minister Martin Smolek and the townrsquos MSP Colin Beattie .Also in attendance were the Czech Consul General from Manchester, Ivo Losman, and the Consul from London, Pavel Duchon.Veronika has already made a positive impact on the Czech ex-pat community by opening and running schools for Czech Scottish children in Edinburgh, Glasgow and Dundee, with the help of her co-director Radka Petersen, who will also be her consular backup.

title: east-end-north-berwick-high-street-close-two-weeks
story: The works, which will be for a -month trial scheme, are due to start on Monday, October  and last for no more than two weeks - though will, say the local authority, ldquorequire a temporary road closure but access for pedestrians will be maintained.It will include:bull Widening of existing pavements through the use of temporary materialsbull New double yellow lines and appropriate traffic signagebull Consolidation of loading bay facilitiesbull Keeping some of the plantersbull Fixing fallen kerbs and broken surfacing of footwaysbull Maintenance of some street lightingCouncillor Norman Hampshire, the local autjorityrsquos environment spokesman, said: ldquoIn , a series of proposals to improve access to the town centre were discussed as part of the North Berwick charrette organised through the local Area Partnership.ldquoMore than  main projects were identied by the local community and a priority was to consider improvements for the east end of the High Street which would create more space for people to walk safely.ldquoAn agreed scheme was ready for construction in early  but was delayed as a result of the Covid pandemic halting all non-essential construction works.ldquoHowever, the pandemic did provide opportunities for temporary changes of public access. As part of the national Spaces for People initiative to create room for social distancing in town centres, a number of planters and reduction of public parking have been in place in North Berwick over the past  months.ldquoInformal consultation has suggested that the increased space and reduced parking has been beneficial to the businesses and wider community.The existing one-way system through Market Place will remain while the trial is ongoing.Following the trial period the design may require to be adjusted before funding is sought to implement a final scheme using appropriate permanent materials.

title: brave-tranent-dad-chased-bike-thief-street-bare-feet
story: Last Wednesday at about .pm, Ewan Reynoldsrsquo sonrsquos mountain bike was taken from their garden at Farsquoside Avenue in Tranent.Ewan explained that the bike, a size small Trek Roscoe  in grey red with yellow writing on the tyres, was taken from the back door of their home.His partner Kirsty heard the culprit outside on the garden stones.When she opened the back door, she witnessed the thief holding the bike in the air and making his way down the driveway.Immediately, Kirsty called for Ewanrsquos help and he raced down the garden in his bare feet to chase the thief up the street.Unfortunately, the culprit made his escape in the direction of the bus terminal at the zebra crossing near Windygoul Co-op.Ewan added: ldquoMy son was absolutely gutted due to the theft as he goes out on his bike every day after school and is always out on his bike at the weekends, as thatrsquos what he and his pals do.The bike has since been recovered from a garden in Tranent.Ewan said he was notied of information about the whereabouts of the bike and retrieved it on Monday evening.

title: residents-plant-wildflower-patch-east-linton
story: The workshop was part of CAELrsquos Wildle Network project, launched this spring.CAEL is working towards a lower-carbon, resilient community, with local nature flourishing, and is dedicated to educating residents about East Lothian landscapes.Jo Gibb,a steering group member, said: ldquoAs well as a climate crisis, we are in the middle of a global bioersity crisis and as a response to this, the Wildle Network aims to create corridors of wildle-friendly gardens, where spaces in gardens are dedicated to creating habitats for wildle through wild areas, water features, wildflower patches, bug hotels and many other options.ldquoThe idea was inspired by the Felixstowe Community Nature Reserve Little Green Space and a number of other communities in the UK have since followed similar models.ldquoAs part of the Wildle Network, open garden days have been organised for people to visit and learn from rowan and elder trees provided for those interesteda demonstration border at East Linton park establishedand workshops on dferent themes organised.At the Wildle Networkrsquos Wildflower Workshop, local residents came together to learn about how to establish and manage a wildflower area dedicated to providing bioerse habitats for wildle.Sally Gouldstone, from skincare company Seilich, ran the workshop, which saw participants sowing a wildflower area in East Linton War Memorial Park.Attendees were also provided with native seeds to take home and sow in their own gardens, with the idea that multiple wildflower patches would be established in the East Linton area.Recently, seeds and a scythe to help manage wildflower areas were purchased through funding provided by NatureScot.The scythe will be made available for the local community to use from the East Linton Tool Library.

title: part-musselburgh-set-removed-east-lothian-constituency-general-elections
story: Changes are being considered to the countys Westminster constituency ndash which until now has exactly matched the county boundaries ndash under proposals being made up by The Boundary Commission for Scotland.One of the proposals is to see Musselburgh residents who live to the west of the River Esk included in the Edinburgh East constituency.That would include areas of the Capital such as Portobello and Duddingston.This map shows the proposed Edinburgh East constituency, included the western part of MusselburghThe rest of the East Lothian constituency would then be renamed East Lothian Coast and would continue to include the part of Musselburgh to the east of the river.This map shows the proposed East Lothian Coast constituency, containing the rest of East LothianThe proposals were revealed today , marking the start of an eight-week consultation.For Scotland as a whole, the number of MPs would be cut from  to .Meanwhile, there would  additional MPs in England, eight fewer in Wales and no change in Northern Ireland.Lord Matthews, Deputy Chair of the Boundary Commission for Scotland, said: ldquoI believe this is a promising start to delivering the requirements of the new rules that mean the number of constituencies in Scotland will reduce from  to , and that each mainland constituency must have broadly the same number of electors.ldquoWe have set out proposals today which do that and are, we believe, a good implementation of the rules set by Parliament.ldquoToday is the beginning of a process and we now want to hear the views of the public.ldquoWe will reflect on responses to the consultation and make changes where appropriate and where the legislation allows us to do so.ldquoWe strongly encourage voters to make their views heard.At the last General Election in East Lothian, Kenny MacAskill won the seat for the SNP by a majority of , over incumbent Labour MP Martin Whitfield ndash Mr MacAskill has since left the SNP and joined the ALBA Party.The proposed changes would have no effect to the existing Scottish Parliament constituencies, which see Musselburgh, Wallyford and Whitecraig included as part of the Midlothian North and Musselburgh constituency, and the rest of the county in the East Lothian constituency.

title: public-say-future-20mph-speed-limits-east-lothian
story: Speed limits throughout towns and villages ndash and on the approach to settlements ndash were reduced last year in the wake of the coronavirus pandemic.The speed limit on the approach to many towns was dropped to mph from pm, with vehicles travelling through built up areas often passing at mph, rather than the mph limit previously in place.Now, East Lothian Council is calling on people to share their views on the scheme and whether it should be made permanent or face adjustments.Councillor Norman Hampshire, the local authorityrsquos spokesman for the environment, encouraged people to take part in the consultation, which runs until November .He said: ldquoThe Spaces for People initiative provided all local authorities with opportunities to create additional space for physical distancing and in East Lothian we were able to introduce a number of measures including mph limits leading into our towns and villages.ldquoThese were implemented under temporary Traffic Orders and we are now consulting on whether to make them permanent andso, whether any adjustments need to be made.When, in March , people were instructed to stay at home to slow the spread of the coronavirus, governments across the UK introduced ious interventions to maintain business, tourism, healthcare and education, in response to the changes facing society.The Scottish Government made pound million available for councils under the lsquoSpaces for Peoplersquo project to mody public spaces, such as roads and town centres, to make it safer and easier for people to walk and cycle for essential trips and exercise.East Lothian secured pound. million of funding and put in place a number of measures, including:The lockdown saw a signicant increase in cycling and, since it has been lted, the Scottish Government has made clear its desire to preserve the features which made this possible.Members of the public can share their views on what should happen to the changes in place by going to eastlothianconsultations infrastructure future-spaces-for-peopleResults are expected to be collated before the end of the year.

title: home-bargains-open-haddington-retail-park-weekend-55-new-jobs
story: The national chain is the latest retailer to open in Haddington Retail Park, with the new shop officially opening its doors for the first time on Saturday at am.Already, Costa Coffee, The Food Warehouse and Aldi are welcoming customers on the townrsquos western edge.Ahead of the opening, Home Bargains also confirmed it would be making a pound, donation to Haddington-based good cause the Lammermuir Larder.Magdalena Cosgrove, the new Home Bargains store manager at Haddington Retail Park, was looking forward to welcoming customers this weekend.She said: ldquoIrsquove worked in the retail sector for many years, but therersquos nothing quite like the buzz of opening a new store.ldquoFour years ago, I helped launch our Craigmillar Shopping Centre site, so I know how much hard work and dedication goes into something like this.ldquoI canrsquot wait to open the store this weekend alongside such a fantastic team ndash itrsquos something that Irsquom exceptionally proud of.The more than ,-square-foot store will offer shoppers a range of products, including homewares, health and beauty essentials, sweets, snacks and drinks, as well as fresh and frozen food.Pat Lemmon, founder of the Lammermuir Larder, welcomed the four-figure donation.The volunteer-led food initiative provides people in need with a weekrsquos shopping, fresh fruit and vegetables, and a meat voucher.Mrs Lemmon, who is also a member of the townrsquos community council, said: ldquoWe are over the moon to be picked as the local group to benefit from this wonderful donation from Home Bargains.ldquoThis money will go a long way in helping many people in the Haddington and Lammermuir area who are currently struggling financially and worried about putting food on the table.A petrol station is also planned for the retail park, with one remaining unit yet to be filled.

title: gas-works-see-road-closures-prestonpans-13-weeks
story: SGN announced that it would begin work to upgrade its gas network in the Prestonpans area on Monday.The work involves replacing ,m of old metal gas mains and service pipes with new plastic pipe, ensuring a continued safe and reliable gas supply to the local community.SGN has planned its work in close consultation with local authorities to reduce disruption as much as possible.The project will be carried out by SGN contractor George Ritchie  Son.During the works, parking restrictions will be in operation allowing safe access to the pipe ndash some road closures will also be required.Temporary traffic signals will be in operation at certain times, which may cause delays during peak periods.Emergency vehicle access will be maintained throughout the work.The gas work will be suspended during the Christmas holidays, with operatives ing early in the new year.Road closures include Prestongrange Terracersquos junction with Prestongrange Road, and Polwarth Terracersquos junction with Gardiner Terrace.To minimise disruption, SGN work will be carried out on a phased basis and not all streets will be affected at the same time.Access to driveways and garages will be maintained unless previously agreed with the occupier.An SGN spokesperson said: ldquoWersquoll be working as quickly as possible to complete our work and will be making every effort to minimise inconvenience to the local community.Suspension of parking is as follows:Prestonpans Community Council is calling for greater clarity on road works in and around the town, ideally in the form of an interactive map showing all the restrictions over time.A spokesperson for the community council said: ldquoInidual roadworks are obviously necessary for the maintenance of our public utilities.ldquoHowever, there is a balance to be struck between maintenance and what can quickly become a public nuisance.ldquoIf roadworks are all planned to minimise distribution, there is currently no way of telling. For example, Blindwells seems to open and close our key access road to the A on a whim.ldquoWith all the building works going on, there needs to be much tighter management, notication and planning.ldquoDevelopers should also be held to schedule and asked to contribute to the local community for unnecessary job overruns and traffic delays.ldquoOne key concern, for example, is the timing of sequencing on temporary lights.ldquoSequence settings can have a huge impact on road users.ldquoThese lights should be independently assessedleft in place longer than a day.ldquoThis is the information technology age letrsquos start using it to manage and monitor our service providers.SGN said it would be writing to residents and other local stakeholders to make them aware of the project.Residents with enquiries about the project can call SGN on   .

title: success-east-lothians-bloom-groups-celebrated-scottish-parliament
story: Aberlady in Bloom, Blooming Haddington, Gford Community and North Berwick in Bloom celebrated success last month at Keep Scotland Beautulrsquos Beautul Scotland awards.The achievements were title: large-part-north-berwick-harbour-closed-saturday-boats-craned

title: day-activities-dunbar-start-pilgrims-walk-cop26-climate-conference
story: Walkers will follow the John Muir Way from Dunbar to Glasgow for the COP climate conference.Ahead of setting off from John Muirrsquos Birthplace, on Dunbarrsquos High Street, a number of family friendly events are taking place in the townrsquos Lauderdale Park.North Light Arts, Sustaining Dunbar and Friends of John Muirrsquos Birthplace are working to put together the special day on Sunday.It is hoped the day will bring together free activities that highlight environmental messages surrounding the ongoing climate emergency, the importance of the human relationship to the earthrsquos soils and nature, a celebration of the pilgrims and the experience of contemplative walking with a special purpose.The events get under way at pm and feature Rowanbank Environmental Arts, a printing workshop by Rebellious Threads, bike-powered flour milling with Shed Therapy, storytelling with the Courierrsquos Tim Porteus and pizza-making with Muddy Buddies.St Annersquos Church will display Stitches for Survival craftivism banners, and offer space for creative prayer, reflection and guided meditations.A led sensory slow walk will begin from John Muirrsquos Birthplace at pm to the harbour, where music and readings will take place within the Battery from .pm.The Battery performance programme includes poetry by Rita Bradd, readings by the Battery Theatre, a special performance by Dunbar Voices of Enough Is Enough, a song written by Oi Musica and Karine Polwart for COP, and a unique Keeper of the Soils ceremony.The day will be rounded off at Belhaven Church Hall with a pilgrimsrsquo supper and a thought-provoking talk by Alastair McIntosh.The pilgrims will set off the following day and make their way to Glasgow in time for the conference, which begins at the end of the month.

title: scotland-cricketers-play-icc-mens-t20-world-cup-kit-designed-haddington-schoolgirl
story: The ICC Menrsquos T World Cup gets under way in the United Arab Emirates and Oman this weekend.Scotland, who start their tournament against Bangladesh this Sunday, will be wearing a design created by Haddingtonrsquos Rebecca Downie.The youngsterrsquos pattern was chosen from more than  entries from schoolchildren across Scotland. title: scottish-parliament-recess-happens-mean-scotland
story: Parliament recesses are breaks from normal order and usually take place several times a year in line with school and bank holidays.What do these recesses mean for politics in Scotland  Heres everything you need to know...Parliament recesses arebreaks in the normal schedule when there are no meetings in the Chamber and no committee meetings.The Ocotberrecess is often seen as an "October holiday" for MSPs, althoughit is unlikely they will take the whole recess to recuperate.The recess allows MSPs to spend an extended period of time in their own constituencyand therefore with their constituents.MSPs are likely to take advantage of this time to maintain or increase rapport with their constituents by attending local events and generally keeping a fairly high profile.Recesses give MSPs time to make the visits that they might in normal times be too busy to carry out.No, First Ministers Questions will not continue during recess.However, Parliament can be recalled over the course ofrecessrequired.Parliament can be recalled from recess on request of the Government.For example, Parliament was recalled during recess in April following the death of Prince Philipto allow politicians in Scotland to pay tribute to the Duke of Edinburgh.Yes, you can still get in contact with your MSP during recesses and they may table questions to ask when Parliament s.The UK Parliament will takerecess from November -.

title: covid-scotland-pregnant-women-left-exposed-delta-wave-mixed-messages
story: Statistics this week from both Scotland and England have highlighted concerns over the numbers of unvaccinated mothers-to-be ending up in critical care, particularly since the Delta strain became dominant.Yet despite growing evidence about the dangers posed by Covid during pregnancy - including increased risks of miscarriage and stillbirth - expectant mothers are not, and never have been, prioritised for vaccination.Instead, mixed messages have fuelled uncertainty over the vaccines safety, with mothers-to-be initially advised not to get it due to a lack of clinical trial data .The third wave, which began in May, coincided with the rise of the Delta iant and with first dose vaccines being offered to people in their s and, mostly from June onwards, to people aged  to Yet even after official guidance changed in April, making clear the vaccines were safe, effective and should be offered to women at any stage of pregnancy, reports surfaced on social media of women being given contradictory information, often by midwives, ranging from vague and non-committal "we cant advise you what to do" to cautions that they should delay.One mother - who wanted the jag - told the iPaper in July that her midwe had urged her "not to be a guinea pig", while another said she had caught Covid after being told "not to risk the vaccine".The consequences of this confusion are crystal clear in figures showing uptake rates which are around a third of that compared to the general population of the same age.: One in fourintensive care Covid patients under- in third waveIn Scotland, two separate reports published over the past ten days have shed some light on the patterns of Covid infection and serious illness among pregnant women and those who had recently given birth.For instance, we now know for the first time - thanks to a Public Health Scotlandreport - that a total of , cases of Covid were detected in pregnancies between March  and August .Meanwhile, analysis by the Scottish Intensive Care Society Audit Grouphas revealed that between March  and September  a total of  women were admitted to intensive care with Covid who were either pregnant on admissionor had given birth in the six weeks prior .From Scottish Intensive Care Society Audit GroupFrom this it is possible to conclude that roughly .% of expectant and new mothers who contracted Covid in Scotland have ended up in ICU coronavirus are necessarily in hospital for that reason.However, given that these caveats apply to everyone - not just pregnant women - how do these figures compare to the general population Well, according to PHS there have been , confirmed cases and  ICU admissions to date in females aged  to .On that basis, the infection to intensive care conversion among young women in general is approximately .% - a tenth of the rate compared to those linked to pregnancies.The number of cases being confirmed in pregnancy has increased over time, in line with the pattern of the pandemic in generalAnother cause for concern is how the pattern of ICU admissions has changed for pregnant women over time.In the course of the first two waves combined - covering the period from March   to May   - a total of  pregnant, or recently pregnant, women were admitted to ICU with Covid out of a total of  female Covid admissions. In other words, just % were classed as obstetric patients.In the third wave, from May  to September , there were  female ICU admissions with Covid, but this time  of them - % - were obstetric patients.None of these  women had been vaccinated, even with a single dose, despite appointments having opened to  to -year-olds in early May and  to -year-olds in late May.: What Israel tells us about boosters, waning immunity and Covid deathsUptake has been "substantially lower", as PHS put it, among pregnant women compared to the general population: of all the women who gave birth in August, just % had had a single vaccination compared, at the time, to around % of  to -year-olds and more than % of  to -year-olds.Some evidence from around the world has also pointed to increasingly severe illness in pregnant women as the virus has mutated - a pattern which appears to be borne out by the data in Scotland where the Alpha iant dominated during wave two before being overtaken by Delta in wave three.The third wave was associated with a steeper rise in Covid ICU admissions among people aged  to As SICSAG notes there "were very few critical care admissions" for obstetric patients during wave one - very probably fewer than five, in fact.By wave three, however, Scotland had seen "increased numbers of pregnant women being admitted to hospital with moderate to severe Covid- symptoms requiring critical care".Of these wave three mothers, % were of non-white ethnicityand % came from the most deprived areas.Groups, coincidentally, known to have lower vaccine coverage.On Monday, data for England revealed  of the  most critically ill Covid patients given extra corporeal membrane oxygenationbetween July and September were mothers-to-be, of whom  were unvaccinated and one had had a single dose.ECMO is administered when a patients lungs are so badly damaged that a ventilator cannot maintain oxygen levels.: Almost  fully-vaccinated Scots died from Covid after restrictions ltedAccording to Dr Sarah Stock, a consultant in maternal and foetal medicine who is co-leading a study into Covid- in pregnancy at Edinburgh University, being pregnant affects how the body responds to infections and "this is probably what were seeing with Covid-".Thankfully, no pregnant women in Scotland have died from Covid.But it seems clear that they have been let down by a toxic combination of confusion and misinformation which has understandably increased their hesitancy and left them under-protected as Delta - combined with a lting of restrictions - fuelled a surge in infections over summer.At the very least, much more needs to be done now to drive up coverage among expectant mothers, particularly as winter - title: glasgow-campaign-events-play-major-factor-boosting-wellbeing-says-report
story: It is just one of the findings of a report commissioned by VisitScotland and the Event Industry Advisory Groupto help to understand and examine how events continue to contribute to Scotlandrsquos wellbeing.The Contribution of Events to Scotlandrsquos Wellbeing report was delivered by Wavehill Social and Economic Research, and led by Dr Bridget McConnell, CBE and Chief Executive of Glasgow Le, which delivers culture and leisure services, as part of her role with the EIAG Health and Wellbeing Economy group.Read more:Glasgow needs an emergency funding deal to lt it out of crisis, say campaignersThe report also highlighted the social aspect of events is recognised as a key driver for supporting mental wellbeing. It added cultural events can play an important role in helping people to cope with stress. Events also have the potential to directly address issues related to social isolation and loneliness, which are both key influencers on inidual wellbeing.Culture can be key to recovery and wellbeingIn   alone, cultural and sporting events held in Glasgow generated an estimated Gross Value Addedof more than poundm for the city and nearly poundm for Scotland.However, as a result of the pandemic arms- council organisation Glasgow Le lost poundmillion with venues closed and events cancelled. And while it has been able to reopen more than  of its  venues, without further funds no more venues can reopen.Read more:Anas Sarwar calls for Scottish Parliament to act on Glasgow funding fightIt is why The Herald has been leading A Fair Deal for Glasgow campaign calling for a new funding deal for the citys cultural offering. And today campaign group Glasgow Against Closures is holding a rally to highlight the ongoing threat to venues.The Herald has been leading A Fair Deal for Glasgow campaignDr McConnell said: "Our much-loved Celtic Connections festival regularly sees visitors from across the world flock to Glasgow, allowing us to show our city at its best. Because of Covid we were forced to deliver a wholly digital event this year, with audiences from more than  countries participating virtually."While it proved to be a real success, with thousands of viewers expressing their joy that we were still able to make it happen, it also reiterated how important physical events are in terms of supporting our mental health and fostering social connection, with many more viewers commenting on just how much they missed attending the live shows with friends and loved ones."Among the reports findings it said one factor that can play an important role in the Covid- recovery is culture. It said the association between cultural activities and wellbeing is well-established and that cultural activities provide opportunities for social engagement, enjoyment, learning, capacity building, civic pride, social solidarity and cohesion.The report said providing greater opportunity to access cultural activities will help to safeguard the wellbeing of people and communities, enabling them to cope better in times of stress including during the Covid- recovery.It added that investment in culture and leisure has the potential to stimulate local economic growth and reduce the financial burden on services, for example through improved educational outcomes, reductions in crime and anti-social behaviour and better physical or mental healthPaul Bush OBE, Director of Events, at VisitScotland welcomed the report saying: "The findings from this research and the recommendations on how to develop the evidence base for measuring the contribution of events to the nationrsquos health and wellbeing, will form an important part of our work going forward including building it in to our National Events Strategy, Scotland the Perfect Stage."Jenny Gilruth MSP, Culture Minister, said promoting a Wellbeing Economy was a top priority for the Scottish Government.Ms Gilruth said: "As this report has highlighted, the erse range of events that take place throughout the country bring social and economic benefits to our communities. Scotland is the perfect stage for events and this research underlines the important role they have to play as we recover and rebuild following Covid-."

title: scotlands-nobel-laureates-celebrated----can
story: ldquoSo we were able to convey to people that this was actually a pretty interesting and valuable concept that people could use in science and it certainly helped my careerhellip but it wouldnrsquot have happenedI was not Scottish, so said David MacMillan, crediting his winning the Nobel Prize in Chemistry with Benjamin List last week to his Scottish education. A pupil at New Stevenston Primary School and Bellshill Academy, he did his undergraduate degree at Glasgow University, which was the foundation for ldquoeverything I have become as a scientist and a person.My husband, Professor Sir James Mirrleeswho was born in Minnigaff, Galloway, would have agreed, going to primary school in Newton Stewart and Douglas-Ewart High School. He depended on bursaries and prize money to pursue an undergraduate degree at Edinburgh University.Richard Hendersonhas a similar story ndash attending Newcastleton Primary near Hawick, Hawick High and Boroughmuir High in Edinburgh, before an undergraduate degree at Edinburgh University.To date,  Scots have been awarded Nobel Prizes since they were inaugurated in .According to Richard Henderson, this is  times greater than the world-average per capita, with only Switzerland and Austria coming close.In , a year after the Nobel Prizes were established, Sir Ronald Ross, of Shandwick, was awarded the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for his work on malaria. He is the grandfather of the current chief of Clan Ross. Since Ross, Scots have been awarded Nobel Prizes in every category except Literature, although the great Gaelic poet Sorley Maclean was nominated for that in .In the past nine years, between  and , there have been eight Scottish Nobel Laureates, an achievement for a country that has a small population of about . million people.In one year alone, , four of the Nobel Laureates were Scottish. All these achievements should have been a cause for national celebration.David MacMillanrsquos award spotlights the fact that Scotland has been very successful in producing Nobel Laureates but has failed in giving them national recognition.Alfred Nobel in Scotland and the  Scottish Nobel Laureates are a valuable part of Scotlandrsquos heritage that has been overlooked for too long. Celebrating Nobelrsquos Scottish connections and our Scottish Nobel Laureates would raise Scotlandrsquos image as a hub of science and discovery and encourage young Scots to realise that everything is possible ndash that there are no limits to their potential.So what can Scotland do to honour its Nobel Laureates  Here are a few suggestions: l create The Scottish Nobel Fund to help finance a series of initiatives to highlight the achievements of the Scottish Nobel Laureates and the le of Alfred Nobel in Scotland l have a permanent display area dedicated to the Scottish Nobel Laureates in the Scottish National Portrait Gallery.In , a portrait of my husband was presented to the Gallery. On show for only a few months, it was put in storage for a decade. It was displayed again in December , after his death that year.Sir Mervyn King, former governor of the Bank of England, at the unveiling of Jimrsquos portrait pointed out: ldquoThis Gallery is the worldrsquos first purpose-built portrait gallery, opened in  and championed by the historian Thomas Carlyle, who wrote that lsquoHistorical Portrait Galleries far transcend in worth all other kinds of National Collections of Pictures whateverrsquo. Scotland led the way and continues to do so.After the death of Scottish Nobel Laureate David Thouless in April , collecting the portraits of all the living Scottish Laureates became a priority.The Gallery had commissioned portraits of some of the Scottish Laureates when the coronavirus pandemic put everything on hold.When Jim received the Nobel Prize in , he said he was both delighted and a little embarrassed at all the attention. Jim had an exceptional mind, and he was also exceptionally modest ndash embodying the values of small-town Scotland where you worked hard and lived without ostentation.Only after Jimrsquos death, I found in an old file box marked ldquoNobel stuff a pile of letters he had received when the Prize was announced. Among the ldquoNobel stuff, was a letter from Margaret Wilson, an old classmate at Douglas-Ewart High. She wrote: ldquoWas it really August  that my mother told me on the evening of my first day at school that you would be the Dux of that yearrsquos intake and added, lsquothat boy will go farrsquo  This bewildered me ndash I did not realise she was talking in terms of what you would achieve academically. I thought she meant you might go to the United States.Another idea would be to have an interactive display in one area of the National Museum of Scotland.Jimrsquos Nobel medal will go to the National Museum, which has been displaying the Nobel medals of Sir Alexander Fleming, Sir James Black and Lord John Boyd-Orr on three dferent floors in glass cases.Instead, feature all the Scottish Laureates in one area using audio visual technology, interactive display boards, photographs and medals,donated. The recent Scottish Laureates could record their stories in their own words. Scottish actors could narrate the history of those deceased. That way, Scottish children and other visitors could learn more about the Laureates and their discoveries.Few of the Scottish Laureates have blue plaques in Scotland. Several, such as Sir Alexander Fleming, are honoured by them in England. Dr David Hannay, chief of Clan Hannay, has organised with the Galloway Preservation Society for a blue plaque to be placed on the cottage where Jim was born in Minnigaff.Letrsquos create an ldquoAlfred Nobel in Scotland Centre with a guided tour of the Ardeer Peninsula in Ayrshire.We should reopen Irvinersquos The Big Idea, closed in , as the Nobel in Scotland Centre, focusing on the le and work of Alfred Nobel and his vast factory at Ardeer ndash which employed , people at its height ndash his le in Scotland, and his legacy of the Nobel Prizes, showcasing all Nobel Laureates and highlighting the Scottish ones.Alfred Nobel took out a British patent for his dynamite in . Failing to start a factory in England, Nobel, in April  ndash  years ago this year ndash established his British Dynamite Company Ltdat Ardeer with the backing of John Downie, the general manager of the Glasgow firm, Fairfield Engineering and Shipbuilding Company. The records are in Glasgow University archives.In a letter to his brother in , Nobel wrote: ldquoPicture to yourself everlasting bleak sand dunes with no buildings. Only rabbits find a little nourishment herehellip It is a sand desert where the wind always blows often howls filling the ears with sand. Between us and America, there is nothing but water ndash a sea whose mighty waves are always raging and foaming. Without work the place would be intolerable.Other parts of Scotland have a connection to Nobel. Some of the rock powder required in the factory process was found in Skye and Aberdeenshire. Nobel bought the Westquarter Chemical Company, near Falkirk, to produce detonators and established another nearby at Redding Moor to supply that with fulminate.He also acquired facilities at Irvine harbour to export his explosives. He bought, as his base in Scotland, Hawthorn Cottage,  Polmont Road, Laurieston, from his chief chemist George McRoberts. It is still standing.As well as the centre, visitors could have a guided tour of the ruined site of the Nobel factory on the Ardeer Peninsula and explore its areas of bioersity.To celebrate this, surely day tours for visitors to the National Museum of Scotland, the Scottish National Portrait Gallery, the Alfred Nobel in Scotland Centre, the site of the old Ardeer factory and the Ardeer Peninsula. This would be a boost to Ayrshire tourism, which already attracts visitors to the Robert Burns Birthplace Museum at Alloway and Culzean Castle.Annual lectures could also be established, one for universities and another for schools, to be given by a Nobel Laureate of any nationality in Scotlandrsquos seven cities in rotation.Finally, why not have a Nobel Laureates woodland  Wangari Maathaiplanted a tree when she learned she had been awarded the prize.The Nobel Laureates should be a source of national pride and all have left a legacy that should be remembered for ever more.

title: richie-berrington-ready-test-best-scotland-begin-t20-world-cup
story: Richie Berrington is certainly grateful to have been given an unexpected opportunity to spend time with his we and son Oliver over the past year due to a lack of cricket opportunities but, ahead of the start of the T World Cup tomorrow, the veteran batter will now be well rested for the challenges ahead.ldquoOne of the positives of the whole lockdown situation was so much special time with the family which obviously you would never normally get, says the  year-old. ldquoGoing from having all that time to now being away again, it takes a bit of time to get used to. But itrsquos great that you have got Facetime and all that sort of stuff now which does make it a bit easier. And the extra sleep helps too.Scotland will need Berrington to be at his bestthey are to achieve their goal of making it through the first round to take their place among the cricket elite in the Super  phase.A lot of water has passed under the bridge since the Saltiresrsquo last involvement in a World Cup back in  when they couldnrsquot make it beyond that preliminary stage but did at least record their first tournament victory against Hong Kong.Since then there have been numerous landmarks, including a first win over a full member side and that momentous victory against England in .The next step will be to win at least two of the group games against Papua New Guinea, hosts Oman and Bangladesh to surge through to matches against the top Test-playing nations.ldquoWersquove had bits of success at dferent times, and some big wins as well against some big teams, adds Berrington. ldquoThe way wersquove progressed even with the lack of cricket in the last year and a half, itrsquos been pretty amazing actually to see how guys have kept raising the bar.ldquoIt would be huge for us to qualy and for Scottish cricket as a whole just to take that next step forward and keep getting more opportunities basically to play more full members and keep pushing our case for us becoming a full member ourselves.Berrington has plenty of World Cup experience to call upon, including that  adventure in India when narrow defeats to Afghanistan and Zimbabwe proved costly.ldquoTo play in a World Cup for your country is one of the greatest things you can do, he reveals. ldquoIt is obviously a great honour.ldquoWhenever you get an opportunity on the international stage you want to obviously perform at your best and hopefully try and win again for your country. You want to play against the best and you want to try and beat the best so in that sense, itrsquos an exciting opportunity thatrsquos coming up.ldquoIt was a pretty cool experience to be honest, playing in India in . Irsquod maybe played there once or twice before but playing a World Cup there was pretty special.ldquoFor us - as it is now - the goal was to get into that next stage and unfortunately we didnrsquot get there. We did get our first ever win against a team at a World Cup, against Hong Kong, so hopefully this time around we can take that next step.ldquoThe first game is Bangladesh so wersquoll be focused on that one. Theyrsquore a very good team obviously but we have full belief that we can push some of these teams with the confidence we have at the moment and the way the form guys are in a moment.On his own future, the South-African born batter is keeping his options open and has entered no thoughts about this potentially being his final bow on the big stage.ldquoI couldnrsquot put a number on it to be honest. Personally I just take one tour at a time and itrsquos just about trying to keep making sure Irsquom doing what I need to do really from a physical point of view and performing on the pitch. The hunger is still there and therersquos nothing better for me than putting on that Scotland shirt. Therersquos still a lot Irsquod like to achieve in the game.

title: first stop for new buses in orkney
story: Stagecoach has today confirmed that the first four brand new buses will arrive in the county on Friday, October .The investment of £. million in  brand new buses is a result of a contract between Orkney Islands Counciland Stagecoach covering an -year period, from  through to .In total Orkney will take delivery of  Volvo buses over coming months, with the remaining nine buses being built by Optare.The first four buses will arrive in Stromness on the evening sailing from Scrabster on Friday, October  before completing their journey to their new home in the Kirkwall depot.By spring  every Stagecoach bus operating in Orkney will be low-floor entry for easy access for all bus users, with easy-clean leather seats and seatbelts at every seat. They will feature contactless payments and live bus tracking on board on public services that bus users can access by downloading the Stagecoach mobile app. The new fleet will also meet Euro  emission standards.David Beaton, managing director at Stagecoach Highland said: “It is an exciting time for us with the first new buses arriving at our Kirkwall depot. Some of our drivers based in our Kirkwall depot have made the trip to collect the new fleet. Once the buses arrive we’ll do some final preparation to get them ready for driver training and use on our services on the island.”Chair of OIC#s development and infrastructure committee, councillor Graham Sinclair said: “It’s hugely gratying to see these four buses arrive in the county, the first of many more which will bring modern, accessible and low carbon buses to the county for the benefit our residents, including school pupils, and visitors.“This is the result of a lot of hard work by officers of the council, in the lead up to the contract being awarded, to explore the ious options for the county and steer us through procurement to what is a cost effective and environmentally advanced solution.“We look forward to the rest of the fleet arriving over coming months and to exploring, with the operator and with funders, possibilities in coming years for tapping into Orkney’s vast renewables potential and bringing on board green hydrogen and electric powered buses.”OIC’s transportation manager, Laura Cromarty, said: “We are delighted to introduce the first of the new fleet to Orkney and look forward to promoting and encouraging the use of public bus services again”.The buses are expected to begin operating on routes across Orkney week commencing Monday, October .copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: restored royal oak bell rings out on eve of anniversary of ships sinking
story: A bell from the battleship HMS Royal Oak has been restored to its former glory and has rang out on the eve of the nd anniversary of the ship’s sinking with the loss of  boys and men.A small ceremony, which included the son of a survivor of the ill-fated ship, was held in St Magnus Cathedral — home to the bell since it was salvaged in the s from the ship’s resting place in Scapa Flow — on Wednesday for the unveiling of the now complete bell.HMS Royal Oak, one of five Revenge#class battleships built for the Royal Navy during the First World War, was anchored in Scapa Flow when she was torpedoed by the German submarine U-.Of Royal Oak#s complement of , men and boys,  were killed that night or died later of their wounds.Now, thanks to the skills of local craftsman Richard Wilson and ropemaker Paul New, from Tyneside, the ship#s bell now has a clapper and tassel — sponsored by Bill Spence.Bill explained how the story unfolded: “When we were planning the commemoration of the centenary of the Battle of Jutland in , we identied an occasion when we wanted to ring the Royal Oak bell as HMS Royal Oak had been engaged in the Battle of Jutland before she was torpedoed in .#The ship and bell survived Jutland and we thought it would be appropriate for her bell to be used as part of the commemoration ceremony however, there was no clapper in it. I thought it might be fitting for the bell to be recommissioned and used again in remembrance of the  lives lost.”Towards the end of , Bill contacted a local craftsman and friend, Richard Wilson, and askedhe could help. It had been hoped to have the clapper made and fitted ready for the anniversary in , however plans had to be delayed due to the pandemic.In the meantime, Richard carried out online research and was eventually able to get inside the Cathedral to measure up, acquiring the bronze for the clapper proved dficult locally so he had to source it online.“It took me around a fortnight to make the clapper in my shed at home mostly using a hobby lathe and a CNC router,# said Richard.#I was a bit taken aback when Bill asked me to do this for him. Obviously, it is a great honour and a privilege for me to be asked considering the history of the ship and the lives lost during the sinking.#Hopefully this clapper will be around for years to come and will be used to commemorate the event each year.”However, this was only half the tale. The clapper needed a tassel — a rope that someone would actually hold to ring the bell.Fran Hollinrake is the visitor services officer and custodian at the cathedral.She said that, having attended several commemorations over the years, her and her husband Andy became friendly with a couple, John and Tracy Welch.John’s father, Stoker Petty Officer John Welch, was on board HMS Royal Oak the night she sank, but he survived.His son, John, was a rigger in the Tyneside dockyards, and spent much of his working le working with ropes, but ill-health prevented John from making the tassel.Instead he passed the job on to his former apprentice and friend Paul New.John and his we Tracy arrived in Orkney this week and were present at the unveiling.John said of his father#s experience on that fateful night: #The night of the sinking he was on deck having a cigarette when the explosion happened. He managed to get off the ship and into the water and was picked up by the Daisy II.#He said he had held on to another chap in the water who was in dficulty,  as he was an excellent swimmer and had medals for le saving and water polo, but when they were both pulled aboard by the crew of the Daisy unfortunately the other chap had died. He was lucky to escape with burns to his hands and face.#After medical attention I think a week or so later he was sent back to Portsmouth to join another ship.“As I far as I can remember he never ed to Orkney, but after the war attended the reunions in Portsmouth on a regular basis. As for his feelings about that night it wasn’t something he went into in great detail, but he did say thathe could get back on the ship he would know exactly where his gold lighter and cigarette case were.#Representing the council, who maintain the Cathedral on behalf of the people of Orkney, Councillor Stephen Clackson also has a personal connection to the Royal Oak, having tragically lost his uncle Ronald George Clackson when the ship went down.He said: “My Uncle Ronny was the closest sibling in age to my dad and his favourite brother. He was very technically minded and joined the Royal Navy on July , , aged ¾, for ‘  ’ years.#After training at the shore establishment HMS Victory, he was posted to the recommissioned HMS Royal Oak as an ordinary seaman on June , , when the ship was expected to be embarking on a -month tour of the Mediterranean.#Looming hostilities set the course of the battleship in another direction, and by August she was in Scapa Flow. My uncle was reported missing presumed killed when the Royal Oak was sunk by torpedoes from the U- in the early hours of October , just a week after his th birthday.#The news was devastating for my grandmother, whose brother had been killed on the Somme in World War I at the same age, and she never really got over it. I often wonder about my uncle’s short spell in Orkney and how he celebrated his last birthday on October , .”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: roundabout resurfacing work to begin
story: oicRoundabout resurfacing work to beginOctober ,  at : amWork to resurface Ayre Mills roundabout is to get underway today, Monday, October .The road works on the roundabout is being carried out in two phases.The first phase of the works will involve closing the access on to the roundabout from Pickaquoy Road and Hatston Brae with a signed ersion route via Crowness Crescent, Grainshore Road, Ayre Road and Junction Road.The second phase will then close the Grainshore Road and Ayre Road accesses on to the roundabout with ersions via Crowness Crescent, Hatston Brae, Pickaquoy Road and Junction Road.The council wishes to apologies for delays and inconvenience caused during the resurfacing of the roundabout, and once again thank the public for their understanding as we carry out this important work.Works recently publicised to start on the A through St Marys, Holm on Monday, October , will now not start on that date.Updates will be provided as above when the new start date is available.To find out more about road resurfacing plans for the next two weeks, visit https:www.orkney.gov.uk News postidcopy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. Here are a few of those:ndash : Coronavirus vaccineThe Queen said her Covid- jab ldquodidnrsquot hurt at all as she encouraged those hesitant about vaccination to ldquothink about other people rather than themselves.During a video call with health leaders delivering the vaccine across England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland, she said her own inoculation in January was ldquovery quick.ldquoOnce yoursquove had the vaccine you have a feeling of, you know, yoursquore protected, which is, I think, very important, she said. vw,vw,px, px"The Queen called on people hesitant about vaccination to think about others ndash : BrexitThe Queen spoke in favour of iniduals seeking ldquocommon ground and ldquonever losing sight of the bigger picture in what was interpreted as a veiled reference to the toxic mood of the public debate around Britain leaving the EU.During a speech at the Sandringham Womenrsquos Institute, she also extolled the virtues of ldquorespecting the other personrsquos point of view.ndash : Chinese officialsThe Queen was caught on camera describing Chinese officials as ldquovery rude.She was overheard making the uncharacteristically unguarded comments during a discussion with a politan Police chief, who had spoken of dficulties in organising the State Visit of Chinese premier Xi Jinping.The Queen quipped that it had been ldquobad luck when she heard that Commander Lucy DrsquoOrsi had been assigned to be Gold Commander of the police operation around the visit.ndash : Scottish independence referendumThe Queen told a well-wisher that Scots Balmoral estate in Aberdeenshire.Later, former prime minister David Cameron had to apologise to the Queen for revealing that she ldquopurred down the line when he informed her of the result of the referendum.He let slip her relief at the No vote in a conversation with former New York mayor Michael Bloomberg which was picked up by TV microphones. vw,vw,px, px"The Queen meets Scotland First Minister Nicola Sturgeon at Buckingham Palace ndash : Abu HamzaThe BBC apologised to the Queen for revealing that she had raised concerns with the Government about why radical cleric Abu Hamza al-Masri had not been arrested.Security correspondent Frank Gardner told the Radio  Today programme about the private conversation he had had with the monarch some years earlier, and the BBC said it and Gardner were sorry for the ldquobreach of confidence.Gardner had told Today: ldquoThis is a conversation we had a little while ago and she did say that she had mentioned to ndash I donrsquot know which home secretary it was at the time ndash that was there not some law he had broken ldquoI wouldnrsquot say she was necessarily lobbying, thatrsquos not for me to say, but, like anybody, she was upset that her country and her subjects had been denigrated by this man who was using this country as a  for his very violent, hateful views.ndash : Apartheid regimeA political storm blew up when the Queen was reported to be dismayed by then Conservative prime minister Margaret Thatcherrsquos ldquouncaring style of leadership and fearful that her opposition to sanctions on South Africarsquos lesson.ldquoWe lost the American colonies because we lacked that statesmanship to know the right time, and the manner of yielding what is impossible to keep, she said during a speech in Philadelphia.That lesson, she said, helped Britain transform ldquoan Empire into a Commonwealth.ndash : Polio vaccineThe Queen made public her decision to have her children, Prince Charles and title: six times over the limit drink driver was caught again just a week later
story: A drink driver who was found drunk behind the wheel just a week after being caught six times over the limit has been banned for  months.Matthew Willmott, , of Lower Voe, was warned at Lerwick Sherf Court on Wednesday he would have been jailed had it not been his first offence.Sherf Ian Cruickshank said it was a ldquovery serious matter and ordered Willmott, who had pleaded guilty to the two charges to, carry out  hours of unpaid work instead.Procurator fiscal Duncan MacKenzie told the court Willmott was first caught drink driving on the A between Tingwall and Lerwick on st August.Another motorist became so concerned by Willmottrsquos driving that he alerted police and followed him to keep officers updated on his location.After pulling Willmott over, officers noticed a ldquostrong smell of alcohol and recently emptied beer cans in the vehicle, Mr MacKenzie said.Willmott was arrested and taken to the police station. He gave an alcohol reading or  microgrammes per ml of breath, which is more than six times the limit.Just a week later, in the early hours of th August, officers on patrol noticed Willmottrsquos car with its lights on in a layby of the A near Voe,Willmott was in the driving seat, with the keys in the ignition. Although the engine was off at the time, officers noticed a rear brake disk was still warm.Willmott was again arrested and taken to the police station. This time he gave a reading of  microgrammes per ml of breath, which is almost four times the legal limit.Mr MacKenzie said the test readings were ldquoextremely high.He applied for the sherf to forfeit Willmottrsquos car, valued at between pound,, and pound,, as part of sentencing.He said the fact Willmott was caught twice in a week showed he was potentially a ldquosignicant risk to the public, which could be ldquomitigated by depriving him of access to his motor vehicle.ldquoHe may well be someone whose judgement is so impaired by his addiction that the risk remains very high, Mr MacKenzie said.ldquoHe has simply not been able to cope, he said.ldquoHe is terried about going to jail,# he added.Mr Allan appealed for the sherf not to forfeit Willmottrsquos car, which he was still paying off to a finance company.He said even at the cheapest estimates it was a ldquosignicant penalty to someone who is at the moment going through the process of applying for universal credit.Sherf Cruickshank agreed not to forfeit the car, saying the financial impact on Willmott would be ldquodisproportionate.He said the community payback order, requiring supervision for  months, was an alternative to custodial sentence.Willmott was ordered to carry out  hours of unpaid work over a year.He was disqualied from driving for  months for each of the two charges, although the period of the ban can be reduced by a quarterhe takes a drink driving awareness course.A man who crashed into the front of a house after a high speed police chase while almost five times over the drink drive limitPupils’ artwork has been damaged by vandals.A dangerous driver almost caused a crash near Lerwick last week.
